title: What will be the closing value of the S&P 500 Index on 19 June 2020 relative to its closing value on 19 March 2020?
possible_answers: Between down less than 5.0% and up less than 5.0%
preds: Moved to 100% having reviewed the market on the morning of the 19th...
Looks like things will stay high for next few days.
The S&P 500 has been behaving irrationally due to the influx of day traders. The short term will be a rise in the S&P 500.

Despite spiking infection rates, the market opened on Monday much higher than Sunday night futures might have indicated; this was helped by the retail numbers for sure.  Even though markets might continue to be rocky, it’s unlikely that they will dip below a 15% increase by Friday.
With only 3 trading days left and S&P 500 at 3124, chances are almost nil of falling below 2770
...because investors are completely unmoored from reality right now.

I think the bad news regarding increased Covid-19 cases and continued economic uncertainty will catch up to investors soon, but not before the closing date for this question.

I'm interested in the unusual investing psychology I am seeing and want to see if assumptions hold.  I believe there is a premium on hope, and that this index is not actually based on the underlying value of the companies in any real sense. It appears more like second guessing how other investors will react to general news and momentum. The S&P would have to drop over 223 points this week to be at or below +15% and while this week may be close to that there still seems to be a good deal of hope of a return to near normal in the summer.
it's already up way more than that, and is trading in a narrow range, most days.  And June 19 is only a few days away.
Covid numbers this week will be a drag on the markets until the spiking states do something. It's too early for those states to act.
Up 15%: ~ $2771 Currently, the index is at $3041.

Current value of S&P is 3041. Value of S&P on 3/19 was 2040. Difference is roughly 30%. With 6 days remaining until 6/19, I feel relatively confident that the market will not decline enough in those 6 days.
It is currently up pretty good.

Equities are extremely over-valued (PG @ 62PE!), having failed to account for the risks of unprecedented systemic damage already sustained, with myriad unknowns yet to come. Our generation has never experienced such an uncertain wild card like a major pandemic, and this extreme level of uncertainty is toxic for markets. Current optimism is misplaced, when in reality, the wreckage of Main Street will severely impact corporate activity. Add to this civil and geopolitical conflict, and a surge in new cases resulting from large recreational and protest gatherings. Almost every expert has added the caveat "all bets are off if a 2nd wave". Since we are somewhere near halftime of the first wave, having never fully appreciated the extent of the current situation and soon-to-be-realized damage, people are making grand assumptions based on grossly incomplete understandings.  I believe all bets are in fact already off, and investors will be taken by surprise for a third time, waking up to the terror as reality sets in. This wide belief that society can pick up where it left off will prove disappointing. Last Thursday's gap-down open was smart money making their exit and likely made a top that sets up a sudden cascade decline, closely resembling the March top and subsequent decline, for a retest of the March 23 low. Friday also showed heavy stealth selling with odd momentum throughout the day. Dumb money may be dancing without a seat. I'm split on the timing because a lot of false data is being thrown around, from global case and death numbers to employment figures, and exceptionally irrelevant news has driven the market ever higher, giving every reason to expect this to continue. As such, timing this market has been challenging. A market-crushing catalyst hiding in the shadows is anarchy. While the US is certainly facing some, quite a few neighbors south of our border are at risk. Disruptions to food supply and the collapse of medical infrastructure will topple more than one government. This is unlikely before June 19, but highly probable before the end of the year. As several of these events occur, global markets will find new lows.
Thursday's volatility has brough the 2770 level back in play, with 10% probability (at weekly implied vol of 55%)

2770 for "below 15% up" vs. actual 3041. Long way.
S&P 500 went up, because "the big money" is now convinced, that Covid-19 won´t be as bad as expected. It went down again afterwards, because the FED was so pessimistic in it´s recent announcement. That´s all included in the current number (and so are the riots). I don´t see any reason, why it should go down another 271 points in less than a week.
Going with the crowd on this.

I think quarterly Index options expiration lies in the week ahead. In the light of this, Thursdays 6% drop indicates,
a) markets are in the mood to take profits from end of March, since ytod-return has already been gigantic. Traders can go sailing or play golf for the rest of the year, bonuses and merits have already been earned.
b) markets now become nervous ahead of options expiry amid uncertainty of US-markets specifics (Pandemic still not under control, election campaigning, rallying in the streets, unemployment still high, weak financial position of US budgets and balances ...)
VIX was 72.00 on 19 March 2020 (high of 82.69 on16 March 2020), and has continuously moderated until 05 June 2020 (24.52). Thursday's drop caused VIX to jump from 27.57 to 40.79, which looks like many in the market don't feel comfortable with their positions and with the scale, length and the early (maybe too early) conclusions investors on average have drawn from recovery efforts + recovery money. Two more trading days with 150 points or 5%+ lost (not unusual with a VIX of 36.09 as of Fri 12 June2020), and we're back in the last but one bucket. http://www.cboe.com/vix/

-5% to 5-15, +5% to 15+. 5 trading days left and S&P is at 3041. It would need to drop another 270 points to be below 'Up more than 15.0%' which would be a ~9% drop from here. S&P 500 has dropped by 9% or more over 5 days only 7 times YTD

QE should be good for another 10-20% upside, on top of the 30% so far.  But, risks abound.  For instance, top 5 stocks make up about 25% of the index, which is highly unusual and in the past associated with market peaks.  If the market sells off, it could sell off quite hard, for instance the same 25% it sold off in the month prior to the start of the competition.
Would need to fall massively in the next two weeks to not reach the highest bin.

May 20: 2972 (23%) Market does still feel over-valued and it seems like any re-opening effect is already priced in to some extent. I would lean more conservatively on the 5-15% range, but put significantly more probability on the up 15% vs. the between +/-5%.

19 May closing is 2922, which is 21% up from 2409.  15% up from 2409 would be 2770 i.e. 10% down from today.
The price has increased 12% from April to May. I give it 50/50 chances of dropping more than 10% by 19 June - there is a slow opening of the US, we could see economic activity resume along the lines of Sweden and Germany. There is bubblyness in the markets, so it's not priced in all adverse news.

down 15%: $2048

up 5%: $2530
up 15%: $2771 delta for the above strike prices follow per [0]

The investment market is disconnected from job loss for now. Money is chasing companies with COVID-related activities (supplies, vaccines, etc) flitting to the next big thing as it hits the news.
if It would be up against the 19 march value, it would be one of the stupidest things I have ever seen in my life. But then again, stupidity is what we forecast.
Depends on how fast people will understand the situation.

We’re still a long way off the bottom of this thing. Challenge is how much policy/stimulus keeps the number up, but the real economy trajectory is stark and negative, within the US and globally, so...

Today May 3 it is up 16% from March 19. However, if deaths go up, commerce does not commence, too many people can’t get back to work, bankruptcies for banks and big corporations then this could fall quickly.

2200 was the recent low in the S&P 500.  Currently the 2793 is where the o/n futures are trading at (as on 4th May).  Difficult to call.  While I feel a test of the 2200 will happen - chances of it to happen in the next 45 days are very slim. And the market had run up significantly since the lows. Maintaining 2770 (up more than 15%) would be tough too.

Personally, I feel we haven't seen the bottom yet nor have we seen the end of this bear trap. On 19 June, several models from systematic traders put the S&P at up ~27%  That isn't a stretch. What is strange(r) or more disconcerting is that traders have been rallying despite 30 million unemployed Americans and an impending oil crisis. Oil producers can't drop production below 60%. It is prohibitively expensive to cap wells and dangerous to crews and equipment to drop production levels. So we'll see! Anyone who can get questions like this right consistently could be very rich; yet "you can comfortably fit all the people in the world who consistently can predict the markets in a mini-van." (I'm not sure who said that, either Jim Paul or Dalio. Also, that is a paraphrase.) At any rate, the market is trading like a group of guys playing poker on the Titanic and waiting to finish this next hand before cashing out.
Same conviction, just tightening the spread. The market is back functioning, the spread of my probability is covering the volatility in the market.
The economic impact of the pandemic is still underestimated by the markets in my opinion.

i don't think there's any single way this could turn out... there'a always the possibility that sentiment freaks out when some agency or another announces job losses or new vaccines or ... etc. likelihood is that money wants to keep itself funded, so things should be better, maybe not WAY better, but at least 15%... otherwise, they're poised to snap up cheap companies during a second round of sell-offs, which won't be worth it unless they go down hard first...

"These numbers strongly suggest we will see a full-blown U.S. recession, but the severity and duration of the recession takes will only be obvious in hindsight" (https://www.forbes.com/advisor/investing/covid-19-coronavirus-recession-shape/) The trend is up now and if a recession is to happen, it is likely that the down stroke of whatever letter it is will still be above 15% (2770).

When the lockdown is over and the economy doesn't snap back, the market will take another hit. As the world-wide resession kicks in the market will take damage. And what we recently saw in oil will happen in other markets, in other words, weird things. The virus and lockdown are just the pin that pricked the bubble.

More earnings reports came out. Bad, but not as bad as expected...
DAL reported earnings of -$0.50 per share, expectations were - $0.71.Their post market share price is currently up more than 3.5%. 
However, Coca Cola’s stock fell by 2.47% yesterday after they reported $0.51 earnings per share, higher than expectations of $0.44.I think this was partially due to concern around the oil price.  I believe this pattern will continue for the majority of S&P 500 companies as they report earnings over the next week.  However, these (potential) gains will only be short term (couple weeks max). Only going to increase 'up between 5% and 15%' by 3%

Using the 2008/09 GFC as a guide, the S&P 500 took 6 months to reach its ultimate bottom after the initial crash in late Sep 2008. As we've seen in this crisis, there was an initial rally for about a month after the first low - but after that the S&P fell to lower levels once investors started to fully appreciate the economic damage.

15% increase = 2770.8 
5% increase = 2529.86
5% decrease = 2288.92
15% decrease = 2047.98 Current price = 2875.56 (up 19.3%) The earnings call for many S&P 500 companies is within the next 2 weeks. Of course, they will be very bad in relative terms, but the market's reaction will be determined by the difference between expectations and reality. Most forecasts are extremely gloomy so I wouldn't be surprised if the market reacts positively to anything better than these, even if they seem catastrophic.  The Reaction to Coca-Cola’s(KO) earnings call tomorrow could be a good indicator. However every company has been affected differently therefore it needs to be taken with a big grain of salt.  I believe the markets have already priced in expectations about parts of America re-opening. The scale of this will likely cause a strong reaction. Anything underwhelming could lead to a price decrease.  Absolutely anything could happen in 60 days. There are unprecedented levels of volatility and the future is extremely uncertain. If anyone is confident about this then they must be a reincarnation of Nostradamus or a time traveller.  I'm going to base my forecast on more immediate indicators and change it regularly.
It's already up 16% but I think a decline over the coming months is likely.

The market has gone up since I last evaluated this forecast, so I'm changing it to reflect that. It is currently at 2722. There's a lot of volatility so it still has some potential to fall a lot more though.

Multiple charts/experts suggest that 2350-2400 was a solid floor for the S&P 500 (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/19/sp-500-would-sink-more-if-it-falls-below-this-level-charts.html). Now obviously that is no guarantee, but considering how strong the economy was before COVID-19 pandemic, it is my opinion that much of the drop was due to overpricing in the market before hand. With so much uncertaintly, investors will react positively to good news, which as of 4/8/20 (the writing of this post), there has not been much of. With that said, the S&P 500 is already up to 2700 (~10% above that 2400 mark). There has been a ton of volatility, so this will likely drop back down at some point, but I feel confident that it will be above or around that 2400 mark by June 19th.

Somewhat more positive given stimulus package

It is currently 6:19AM, March 27, 2020. The US stock market participants have increasingly understood the growth rate of Covid-19.  However, many people fail to see the likelihood of A)  hospital staff getting sick  B) ventilators being rationed (the elderly being tiraged to death)  C) deliverymen and postal workers spreading Covid-19  D) denial that viruses spread inside hospital via the HVAC systems  E) hospitals having insufficient abilities to segregate Covid-10 patients from other sick people  E) refusal, so far, to activate the National Guard or US Military to force (using bayonets it necessary) crowds to dissipate  F) prison's delays in releasing those being held awaiting trial (not convicted of anything,  just awaiting trial) in crowded facilities and with poorly paid staff and god knows what level of PPE  G)  Its easy to make hopeful announcements, and blatant lies, from a podium, but hard to hide dead bodies H) the Republican controlled legislatures have been slow, by weeks, in enacting social distancing and closing facilities allowing Covid-19 to spread without detection (no testing kits)  and last but not least  I) Donald Trump will be our president through the entirety of 2020.  God help us.

Coronavirus disruptions significantly exacerbate underlying issues in the economy (record high asset valuations, P/E ratios, as well as leverage and corporate debt loads), and the spill over risks to the credit and housing markets are not yet being properly valued by the stock market.
I think the SP will remain very volatile based on the news of the pandemic, number of infections and number of deaths.  I think the 2 trillion dollars will help stabilize the markets.
The stimulus and downward trend of COV-19 by then ought to raise the market.
With markets still being expensive while macro economics uncertainly remains high, the overall market direction would continue to point down.

Mitigation strategy relatively successful, vaccine and treatment medicines experiments show promising results, "China Inc." and global supply chains start to come back online gradually.  Economic stimulus package includes MLB and free tickets for citizens.
initial estimate based mostly on intuition, for future calibration

We will have turned the corner and be back to business as usual in the US

The Index moves more on sentiment rather than financials. In three months we will see a lot of unwinding of leverage and bankruptcies. The current fall is only considering loss of revenue. Current level of S&P is same as the level in Dec 2016. In 2008 crisis the fall was spread out over 1 year. The financial impact of this is still unknown
Expect a sharp recovery from a demand shock.   Epicurve may flatten by second week of April and market sentiment will improve then.

March 22, 2020: The market is still in a reactionary phase and I do not believe it has priced in the worst of what is to come. I believe that the unclear message at the federal level and the disjointed state reactions will cause this virus to spread and persist. The economic impact will have reached steady state and the reality of a 12 to 18 month reality will have set in. I believe that reality to mean that the social distancing will remain and that economic impact will have to be priced in meaning a drop compared to what it was on March 19, 2020 when the reality of the situation was in its development phase.

last 5 years 20 3 month periods - 12 without 5% change, 4 with 5% increase, 2 with 5% decrease, 1 each 15% change. Lowered probability of market staying equal and added 5% to high variance possibilities

Difficult to predict but by June the coronavirus numbers should be coming down. Hope will drive the markets up. The grand stimulus will also dampen the downward spiral. I am going to change more from up to down because the world economy impact will mean slower recovery.

We will not be out of the woods by any stretch... while a slim chance of a spike, the equity market is much more likely to fall precipitously more with any recovery being slow and realization that the deficit will mean years of austerity.

Its most likely that the virus is under control by june. The economy will be hurt but the fical aid is huge. Rates will be low. TINA will be back, and stocks will be up.
The virus will impact economy further however governments will try to prevent job losses and bancruptcies as much as possible.
The virus will drag on and the economy will take several years to recover.

SP 500 high was 3400 and low 2400.  Stock prices run based on future expectations. A 15 percent increase puts the index at 2760.
Covid 19 should be in remission with trepidation about winter return.  Oil prices will still be below 40 dollars since inventories are filling quickly. Air travel will stil be in the toilet. Consumer spending may be up with the free mkney but that won't last long. Fed may raise rates but they are so low financials will still return little. Real estate may shine and health care too.
